title: Israel observes Holocaust Remembrance Day amid Gaza war – DW – 05 / 06 / 2024
message:
This year's Holocaust Remembrance Day comes amid the ongoing war in Gaza, where more than 100 Israeli hostages are still being held by Hamas.
Israel's Holocaust Remembrance Day, or Yom Hashoah, takes place every year in April or May according to the Hebrew calendar, whereas International Holocaust Remembrance Day is observed on January 27.
According to official figures, 132,826 Holocaust survivors still live in Israel, the creation of which in 1948 came just three years after the end of World War II and the defeat of Nazi Germany.
This year, Israeli hostages released from captivity in Gaza and families whose relatives are still being held captive also joined the march.
"In the aftermath of the October 7 war crimes committed by Hamas, the world has seen the worst wave of antisemitic incidents since the end of the Second World War," the report stated.

- Holocaust Remembrance Day observed in Israel
- International Holocaust Remembrance Day observed on January 27
- Creation of Israel in 1948, three years after the end of World War II

- Israeli hostages released from captivity in Gaza

title: Hope of Israel Congregation in Roanoke educates during annual Holocaust Remembrance service
message:
ROANOKE, Va. – Dozens gathered at the Hope of Israel Congregation for their annual holocaust remembrance event.
It was an event that was held two weeks after Passover to remember and reflect on the horror of the Holocaust.
In the flicker of candlelight, heavy hearts gathered at Hope of Israel Congregation in Roanoke to honor the roughly 6 million people killed during the Holocaust.
You’ll see people of all ages here, and it’s important for us to never forget,” Maynard Keller, Elder at Hope of Israel Congregation, said.
Samuel Cox, a Holocaust historian, shared stories of Holocaust survivors he has spoken with over the years.

title: Between  New Pumbedita  and  Altneuland : A century of the law that divided the Jewis
message:
At the end of the 19th century, millions of Jews began a rapid and massive migration to the United States.
Thus, the notion arose that Jewish immigration should be restricted, fueled by stereotypes that Jewish migrants were criminals and carriers of diseases.
Almost half of the Jewish people reside in Israel today, while the other nearly half reside in the United States.
David Ben-Gurion himself engaged in a fierce confrontation on the subject with the Jewish community in the United States, which culminated in the Blaustein-Ben-Gurion agreements in the 1950s.
Looking back over the long century since that discriminatory law altered Jewish history, it's impossible to say that "sweet came out of bitter," not after millions perished in Europe.
event_breakdown:
1. In the late 19th century, millions of Jews migrated to the United States.
2. Stereotypes emerged suggesting Jewish immigrants were criminals and carriers of diseases, leading to calls for restrictions on Jewish immigration.
3. Today, approximately half of the Jewish population resides in Israel, while the other half resides in the United States.
4. David Ben-Gurion engaged in a confrontation with the Jewish community in the United States, resulting in the Blaustein-Ben-Gurion agreements in the 1950s.
5. Reflecting on the impact of discriminatory laws, it's acknowledged that the outcome was not entirely positive, especially considering the millions who perished in Europe.

title: Columbia University cancels commencement amid protests
message:
WASHINGTON (NEXSTAR) – Just a few days before Columbia University’s graduation ceremony, the school announced it would cancel commencement.
Columbia University said it would hold smaller school-based ceremonies “rather than the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15.”“A small group of people went too far and cost their classmates this important event,” White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said.
The White House said the president understands the frustration students feel from this decision.
“These are graduates who are going to miss out on an incredibly important day of commencement,” Jean-Pierre said.
Columbia University joins other schools that have either canceled their own graduations or beefed-up security for the event.
event_breakdown:
- Columbia University cancels commencement ceremony just days before the scheduled date.
- White House Press Secretary comments on the cancellation, stating that a small group of people caused the cancellation.
- The President of the United States expresses understanding of the frustration felt by students due to the cancellation.
- Other universities also cancel or increase security for their graduation events.
